awd_titl_txt: Resilient and Extreme-Event-Aware Microgrid-Based  Distribution System Architecture and Power Management
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to improve the resiliency of power distribution systems and make them more reliable.  To reach this goal, it is proposed in this project to break the distribution system into many small power systems (e.g., the power system of a neighborhood), each called a micro-grid (MG).  Each MG of the multiple-MG distribution system architecture can have one or more power generation sources (including renewable generation) and loads. Each MG and the components of the MG have an intelligent agent (i.e., a computer).  These agents will have local information about the MG and its components, and they can communicate with their neighboring MGs and collectively will determine the best operating scenario of the generating sources and loads within the MG, based on the availability of resource and the market price of electricity they receive from the utility.
 
 Under normal condition, the MGs are interconnected and together they form the power distribution grid.  However, in the event of an electrical fault, the MGs can separate from one another, and the isolated faulty MG can go under repair while the healthy MGs will continue operating and be controlled independently and connect in network. When the faulty MG is repaired, it will return to service, and the MGs will form the original interconnected architecture and return to normal operation.  
 
 The fundamental issues the project seeks to address through the proposed approach is:  it is much easier to monitor and control each MG compared to the large power system.  The proposed approach will be implemented on real distribution system models to show that the resiliency and reliability of the system are improved. Clearly, improving the resiliency and reliability of the power grid advances the power engineering field as well as serving the national interest, thus benefiting the society.  Moreover, the exploring of the proposed scientifically-based approach promotes the progress of science. And, finally, the project supports education. The opportunity for the students to work on the project gives them invaluable experience in the important field of power engineering.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcome Report for the General Public

 

The goal of this project was to develop a novel real-time microgrid (MG) power management framework and test its resilience and its awareness and tolerance for extreme events. Another goal was to work toward establishing a comprehensive framework for a multiple-MG distribution system and evaluate its resilience. Both the goals were accomplished successfully through computer simulation. We were also able to investigate (again through computer simulation) the state estimation of distribution systems using data-based (machine-learning-based) approaches. The outcomes of the research project are summarized below:

 

  1. We developed an intelligent power management strategy for a MG (as opposed to super-grid). MG is the cornerstone of smart grid. This was done successfully.
  2. We then investigated survivability of microgrids under extreme events, such as hurricane and flooding. Appropriate planning, scheduling and preventive strategies were developed to improve the resiliency of the MG, in case of an extreme event with an emphasis on the preparation of the MG for survival during the extreme event, from electrical point of view.
  3. We developed machine learning algorithms for power management of an MG and tested its power management and resilience.
  4. We also developed and tested an agent-based power management scheme for a four-MG distribution system benchmark and tested its resiliency when one of the MGs is faulted. Under this scenario the system survived supplying all its critical loads with the cooperation of the agents of the other MGs.
  5. We developed novel state estimation techniques based on machine learning for power management of active distribution networks (ADNs). ADNs are distribution networks that include distributed generation, such as windfarms and solar farms. State estimation is used by the utilities to predict the voltage (magnitude and angle) at each bus of their system and check for safe operation of the system within a specified margin.
  6. To satisfy the broader impacts of the project, a book targeted for the general public, was prepared, and published, titled ‘Smart Grid: Simple Language,” Lambert Academic Publishing, January 2022, available on Amazon by typing the title of the book in Amazon search engine. The PI (hnehrir@montana.edu) has the copyright of the book.
